title: 113_s1998
content: The Act titled "Native Adult Education and Literacy Act of 2014" focuses on adult education and literacy programs for American Indian, Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian, and Tribal College or University populations. The Adult Education and Family Literacy Act is amended to include Tribal Colleges or Universities in various sections, aligning with the Native Adult Education and Literacy Act of 2014's focus on education for Native populations. The Adult Education and Family Literacy Act is amended to include Tribal Colleges or Universities in various sections, with a focus on education for Native populations. Paragraphs are renumbered and percentages reserved for specific sections are adjusted. SEC. 244. American Indian, Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian, and Tribal College or University adult education and literacy. The Secretary awards grants to Tribal Colleges or Universities and Native Hawaiian educational organizations for innovative programs enhancing life skills and transition to employability and postsecondary education. Technical assistance is also provided for program administration. Eligibility requires submission of an application to the Secretary. The Secretary awards grants to Tribal Colleges or Universities and Native Hawaiian educational organizations through grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements. Funding is awarded on a competitive basis for not less than 3 years. The Secretary may consider certain factors when making awards, and applications must include specific descriptions. The organization must include a multiyear strategy in its application to increase the number of adult American Indian, Native Hawaiian, or Alaska Natives attaining a secondary school diploma. Eligible activities under the grant include adult education, family literacy services, English literacy programs, opportunities for qualifying for a diploma, and demonstration projects for professional development. The curr_chunk discusses the development activities aimed at addressing the educational needs of American Indian, Native Hawaiian, and Alaska Native adults. It defines a Native Hawaiian educational organization as a nonprofit organization serving the education needs of Native Hawaiians with expertise in education and research. The curr_chunk states that the individual has expertise in research and program development.
